body.p:
Atto Genl.s Office
Frankfort 9 Feby. 1861.
Govr Magoffin

I am of opinion that the present called session of the Legislature, like one if its regular bi-ennial sessions is limited by the constitution to sixty days unless extended by a two thirds vote. The words of the constitution are "nor shall a Session of the General assembly continue beyond sixty days except by a vote of two thirds of all the members Elected to each house" (Sec. 24 of Art. 2.)
And that the sixty days named in the constitution are days of actuall Session -- not counting days of recess. --

I am influenced to the opinion that this is the proper construction among other things by what may be seen in Sec. 13 of Art. 3. where power is given the Governor in certain
case of disagreement ^of the two Houses^ of the Legislature with respect to the time to which they may adjourn, to adjourn then "to such time as he shall think proper not exceeding four months." Now this is manifestly inconsistent with a sixty day session if your adjourn the Legislature four months and at the same time count the days of recess. But if you exclude the days of recess and count only the days of actual session then there is no conflict with the previous part of the Constitution.

Yours Respy
A. J. James Atto Genl
